user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                              status;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_destroy(&(impl->id)); /* 0 = success */

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_MutSemDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t OS_impl_mutex_table[OS_MAX_MUTEXES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t id;
} OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_SEM_FAILURE (-6)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t OS_impl_mutex_table[OS_MAX_MUTEXES]
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment is a data object definition, not executable code, so it cannot be "unreachable code." The array OS_impl_mutex_table is referenced by OS_MutSemDelete_Impl via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, so the function accesses the array at runtime. There is no code path shown that can never be executed. (Note: even if OS_MAX_MUTEXES were zero this would be an array-size/definition issue, not an instance of unreachable executable code.)
